awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Elucidating the Role of Titanomagnetite in Vesiculation of Silicic Magmas
awd_abstract_narration:
The formation of bubbles (or volatile exsolution) from silicate melt is the most important phase transformation occurring in magmas en route to the surface during an explosive eruption. As dissolved magmatic species H2O and CO2 exsolve and produce a separate vapor phase, magma buoyancy and magma ascent rate increase. Bubble expansion driven by decompression accelerates vesiculation, further increasing magma ascent rate, and thereby the potential for increasing conduit overpressure. Thus, the processes governing volatile exsolution and outgassing, and particularly the timing of initial vapor phase nucleation with respect to depth in the conduit, control a magma's explosive potential. A key unresolved aspect of eruption of crystal-poor silicic magmas is whether bubble nucleation occurs homogeneously (in the bulk fluid) or heterogeneously (aided by a substrate). The distinction is important because homogeneous bubble nucleation requires substantively larger pressure overstepping, or supersaturation than heterogeneous bubble nucleation.  Magnetite crystals are known to enhance the rate of bubble nucleation by providing energetically-favorable substrates, and yet failure to detect a sufficiently high abundance of these crystals in natural pumice has supported the inference that bubble nucleation occurs homogenously. However when numerical ascent models are supplied with measured bubble number densities and executed specifying homogeneous bubble nucleation, the predicted decompression and ascent rates are not only inconsistent with independent assessments but also present physical paradoxes. This study explores the possibility that nanometer sized magnetite particles are present in magmas prior to eruption, and that these crystals trigger bubble nucleation at much lower supersaturation values (i.e., at greater depth in the plumbing system) than would occur in their absence. This proposal provides educational opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students, and highlights participation of under-represented minorities at the University of Hawaii and Montclair State University (NJ). Professional development for Natural Science educators will be provided through a series of workshops focusing on local geology, volcanology, and Earth processes operating over short and long time scales.

This project addresses the question: do bubbles nucleate homogeneously or heterogeneously in explosively erupting rhyolite magma? The objectives of the work to be undertaken are to ascertain whether plinian rhyolite pumices contain nano-scale titanomagnetite crystals in numerical abundances that rival those of bubbles and to quantify the potential influence of titanomagnetite crystals in bubble nucleation. Addressing these issues is critical for understanding eruptive processes at a fundamental level and is of practical significance in the numerical modeling of conduit flow dynamics and thus assessment of volcanic hazard. The work plan centers around two tasks: (a) applying techniques of rock magnetism to characterize the number density and size distribution of titanomagnetite crystals in nominally aphyric pumice clasts spanning a range in bubble interconnectivity; and (b) performing novel laboratory crystallization experiments utilizing fO2 modulation to isolate the influence of titanomagnetite from other variables. Magnetic characterization (resolving the magnetic domain states, particle number densities, and size distributions of submicron titanomagnetite crystals) is promising because it lowers the detection limit of sparse Fe-Ti oxides by several orders of magnitude relative to traditional electron microprobe imaging. Pairwise measurement of clast permeability, to be obtained for a suite of natural rhyolites spanning a range in eruption parameters and textural attributes, will facilitate determination of magnetite-bubble nucleation chronology. In an experimental task, magnetite stability will be manipulated using ambient fO2 in order to generate rhyolite magma containing populations of magnetite crystals that span large ranges in number density and volume fraction. A subsequent vesiculation step will evaluate the quantitative control of magnetite nanoparticle number density on the bubble-formation process.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
A suite of four projects supported by this award addresses the issue of H2O vapor bubble nucleation in high-silica rhyolite liquid. The major goals were to ascertain whether rhyolite pumices contain nanoscale crystals in numerical abundances that rival those of bubbles (numbering in the quadrillion per cubic meter) and to quantify the potential influence of these crystals in bubble nucleation with novel experimental approaches.
We undertook a combined textural and magnetism study of the products of four large-volume explosive eruptions of nominally crystal-free high-silica magma. The petro-textural analysis consisted of quantification of pumice clast porosity and permeability and the characterization of bubble population statistics using whole clasts, polished thin sections, and high-spatial resolution micro-computed tomography. Because the crystals we sought to examine are in the magnetite family, the samples were amenable to characterization using the techniques of rock magnetism. The PI of the collaborative arm of this proposal tailored methods for these sample types and directed acquisition of the magnetics measurements. The combined analyses proved that that explosively-erupted pumice representing a wide range in eruption intensities and pre-eruption storage conditions-- having low total iron content and few visible crystals-- contain extraordinarily high number-concentrations of nanometer‐sized magnetic particles.
The question of whether crystals were abundant enough to stimulate bubble nucleation answered in the affirmative, we undertook an even more detailed study of rhyolitic pumice, obsidian, and vesicular obsidian from the 1060 CE Glass Mountain volcanic eruption of Medicine Lake Volcano, California to critically evaluate the relative timing of crystal and bubble formation. By examining a range of products from the same magmatic system but representing different eruption intensities, we sought evidence supporting the possibility that crystals formed after the magma started to ascend.  However, all available observations (thermodynamic modeling of the pre-eruptive phase assemblage, permeability measurements and magnetic alignment of particles) suggest the opposite: the existence of magnetite crystals preceded eruptive ascent and thus vesiculation of the magma. A major outcome of the work is direct support for the notion that magnetite crystals promote vesiculation of high-silica magma, by providing ‘seeds’: i.e., surfaces on which H2O vapor bubbles form. This is essential information for numerical modeling of magma ascent and eruption dynamics.
A second major branch of the project attempted controlled laboratory experiments to determine just how helpful magnetite particles are for promoting bubble nucleation and to examine the wetting relationships for various crystal-liquid interfaces. A series of experiments stimulated vesiculation of rhyolite liquid containing different populations of magnetite crystals. Among the sub-micron population of magnetite crystals, the small-and-growing crystals appear to be more efficacious for bubble nucleation than large-but-dissolving crystals. This result may be due to differences in particle shape (curvature) or subtle differences in the chemical composition of the liquid surrounding crystals. Another set of experiments compared the tendency of silicate liquid to adhere to different mineral surfaces and frame this wetting behavior as the balance between liquid-solid surface energies. We were able to reject the null hypothesis that all solids (including magnetite) are wetted equally by silicate liquid. This outcome is the first important step toward evaluating the role of solid-liquid energetics in magma vesiculation and determining why (and indeed whether) magnetite is truly special in this regard or merely suitably abundant at the suitable spatial scale; i.e., the mineral phase most likely to be in the right place at the right time at the right concentration and size.
This project supported the training and professional development of a graduate student, whose dissertation is entitled Elucidating the Role of Titanomagnetite in the Vesiculation of Silicic Magmas from Observations of Natural and Experimental Samples.


Last Modified: 04/29/2024
Modified by: Julia E Hammer
